name: Devastating critical cleric / pale master build
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi all!

I thought I would try my hand at trying to create a devastating critical cleric / pale master build.

Thought it would be time to try another build on WoG soon, I'm stuck at Rary's place and can't progress further which is a little frustrating. I think I have the right key (it says it unlocks the main tower) but it seems to not work. 

Anyway whilst I'm thinking about what to how to progress time to make some plans and get help from those who know better!

I thought I should choose a strong class (cleric) with a strong feat (devastating critical), and add pale master build for me to learn the class.

RDD is probably easier and stronger with better stats but what the heck, learning is the goal here.

Sources of inspiration:
Maximillan Kane's The Dark Orcish Shaman (the-dark-orcish-shaman-cleric-20-bard-4 ... 35357.html)
Mithradates Hierophant of Velsharoon (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... html#page1)

Being a bit pale and sickly looking unfortunately his constitution isn't the greatest but this can be buffed up with a endurance spell or items. I think Avado wrote that would be ok, somewhere in his legacy ECB forum posts (risking his divine wrath right now if I'm wrong). He also wrote Wis 19 would be ok

I wanted to make the most of the bard class skills with skill dumps so I didn't want to weaken int too much. I could have ditched discipline as a skill but the thought of being disarmed made me pause.

I think UMD 20 is enough to use all scrolls as a bard without chance of arcane failure, but correct me if I'm wrong

I like undispellable buffs. On WoG every second monster casts greater dispelling on you at least twice every battle. I could have got epic warding and EMA if I went C20/B4/PM16. 

I wanted to fit zen archery somewhere but was running short on feats.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Lose 1 strength, take 1 more great strength in place of toughness, net gain +1 fortitude & 1 point in a minor stat, plus you get the hit points up-front.

Also, lose 5 sp from concentration & put them in umd, I think you'll need 25 for using the boots from the dwarven mines.


Q: Why kukri? You are medium size & don't have twf/itwf, from what I see. Do you just like the weapon?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I was thinking the same thing about the choice of using a kukri.  I would take Martial Weapons instead of Exotic Weapons, and use a scimitar.  It has the same critical threat range but a higher base damage, and there are probably more of them around.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Thanks Valerfor and Empyre65! That was super fast!

I'll drop kukri for scimitar. 

I chose kukri because of the crit range and I had a choice between exotic and martial I guess! Exotic sounds more... well.. exotic...

Trouble is the exotic weapon feat ranged weapons seem average, like its pretty much just shurikens it seems and 1d3 is pretty unimpressive, and I think I would rather have access to a mighty longbow of some sort.

There was a scimitar of speed I picked up along my journey so there are definitely good scimitars out there, and true, there aren't that many great kukri's

I started with Str 18 to try to get Dev Crit asap (like at level 30) but dropping the str does make the character stronger at level 40. Level 33 for dev crit is not too long to wait. I put the spare point into cons in case of a odd endurance spell roll.

Anyway that was super great of you to comment. I've adjusted the build with an edit to the main post. I'll let this sit in the forum for a bit before I will start to play test this

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Another idea would be to use a dagger, which is the only Simple weapon with a wider critical threat range than just 20, and then use the feat freed up by not taking Weapon Proficiency to take Weapon Focus: Morning Star, so you can have 1d8 blunt damage at your disposal for crit-immune enemies.

Even if you stick with what you have now, carry a morning star with you, or if you go with the scimitar idea, carry a warhammer or heavy flail (or both).  Even with no feats for it, a blunt weapon might sometimes be the best choice for a situation.

Ninja'd, but this post might still be helpful.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I seem to recall Mick looking to build a Dev Crit Cleric a few years ago. If he completed the build then he didn't share it with us (boo), but he might have some insight to offer?

I'm cautious on this one, but might it be worth dropping CON down and boosting INT by 2? Those extra 43 skill points could be really helpful in maxing everything you already take and maybe give a smattering in something else.

Other than that, and while I fully concur with Empyre and Valerfor as far as scimitar is concerned, it's a judgement call whether to take Martial Weapon Proficiency rather than sticking with the Cleric weapon choices, then taking Knockdown instead (who'd have thunk I'd ever make that suggestion?).

Just thoughts...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Cool suggestions. I liked Mick's Dev Crit Cleric/Monk/CoT, if this is the build you were wondering about Stag (dev-crit-cleric-t2354618-s10.html)

Empyre's suggestion is not bad. To use dagger to get another feat. Mithradates did that with his dev crit cleric/bard/pm build. If I want a two handed bludgeoning weapon I could always grab a quarterstaff plus cast a few spells from the charges inside them if its magical. There are great feats I could get in exchange for sure. 

I think though I'd like to stick with scimitars for the extra 5% crit threat range (10% if keen) compared with daggers. It's like a 5% - 10% increased chance of enemy death per hit, and with 4 attacks per round with a sky high threat roll from cleric buffs... well you get the picture. Can also use UMD to cast Keen Edge from a scroll on a scimitar which one probably can't with a dagger (has to be intrinsic to the dagger). Martial weapon proficiency gives me access to a whole bunch of great weapons like heavy flail if they are crit immune plus bows which is good (I'm kind of underwhelmed by the damage dealt by slings). Should be able to hit them with the silly cleric AB buffs this character will have access to even I don't have a weapon focus in the weapon in question.

Edit: Whoops got the maths wrong. It's a 10% increased crit threat range (with improved critical) scimitar (15-20) vs dagger (17-20), 15% increased crit range if keened scimitar (12-20) vs dagger (15-20)

Edit 2: forgot to respond to Stag RE int 14 vs 12. I thought about it, I love skill points. Avado was an advocate for keeping cons low in cleric builds (like he says no higher than 10!). Trouble is this dude is gonna want to front line, and 300 odd HP is not a huge amount right now with Cons 12.  I want to think about it a bit more and get back to you. bit of pondering. Avado might be right, who knows?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If you want to play the dev crit game (play mods and pws where you have it and have to defend against it), there are several tactics you can use.
You can be crit immune, meaning PM or items with the crit immune ability.
You can have very high saves, so you beat the DC, meaning saves feats and  CoT or Paladin/BG or items with high saves bonus.
You can have a very high AC so no one* can confirm a crit on a roll of 20.
(*unless they roll 20 twice, and that happens once in 400 times.)
My dev crit cleric focuses on saves.

If you for a moment are willing to forget about dev crit, I will point at a build of mine that takes cleric and bard to their sweet spots. Look up the "Spirit and Steel" build in the 40s section.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Just a quick apology for forgetting about your Dev Crit Cleric, Mick. Of course, I could say that I wouldn't have if it was in the level 40s forum, but that would be wrong of me...

That's why I like the (Ftr xx/ Insert Tumble Class Here xx/ CoT xx), type of builds, so much room for tweaking, the builder's dream & light on cheddar, which is also good for the cholesterol.

This is lovely advice! As far as I know WoG has no crit immunity items so PM is quite  valuable

Just a minor comment, thank you for pointing out the rolling 20 twice. I was VERY curious about that. I haven't played in a lot of high magic environments where a game of 20s is extremely common and I do very much value your experience. 

This is from the wiki (https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Threat_roll):
Since 20s do not automatically hit for a threat roll, a critical hit cannot be scored against an opponent whose armor class(AC) exceeds an attacker's attack bonus by more than 20.
They haven't quoted any sources and there is no talk section so I felt very unsure about this advice. 

So I game tested this. Hope that is ok. 

My intention is to try to find the truth of the mechanics not to prove the wiki right or wrong etc etc... (This is a dangerous tendency by the way: the saying 'curiosity killed the cat' is one example, and the house arrest / trial for heresy of Galileo Galilei for supporting heliocentrism - the idea the earth orbits the sun - thankfully the NWN Wiki probably doesn't have the power of the papacy, the ECB on the other hand... *gulp* why am I doing this...)

Pretty good character creator module: 
This is a dragon with an artificially boosted AC to 100 from sources of natural AC (5), Dexterity (19), Dodge (20 from dragon shape), Deflection (20 - from +20 armor then transferred with druid polymorphing), Innate (10), Tumble (8), Monk wisdom AC (18). 

He has uncanny dodge, but has to keep hitting opponents, otherwise his AC will drop to 74 (loss of Dodge and Tumble AC - correct me if I'm wrong). 

His opponents will gain +2 AB from flanking. (if my understanding of the mechanics is correct - it is a total black box to me sometimes!)


Spawn 50 million gazillion level 40 fighters with devastating critical:


Check the combat logs for anything interesting:

Here are the double 20 rolls I got, they are super rare. I got two double 20 non-critical hits. Perhaps I missed a few more, there were a lot of attacks going on. 

I also got one non 20 devastating critical hit event when I didn't have dodge and tumble AC active.

That last devastating critical roll doesn't quite make sense to me. Maybe the AC drops further in other ways when flatfooted. Maybe someone else can point out something I've missed. Or assume its part of the black box of NWN mechanics - too complex, too hard to understand.

Anyway AC being able to create immunity against critical hits even with double 20s, based on one experiment, I think the wiki is correct in an extremely high AC can create immunity to critical hits can occur, but one has to watch out for being flatfooted (ie drinking potions or knockdown, stun etc) otherwise Dodge, Dexterity (if no uncanny dodge) and Tumble AC will become inactive and the AC will drop and one will become susceptible to criticals.

Addit: agree Val - no space to move with the feats. Reliant on constitution buffs to get that HP up too! It is a fair price to play in terms of balance for having both the cleric class, devastating critical and the palemaster class. Anyway my view - I am an intermediate level player, I need a crutch to succeed in a challenging persistent world, make the most powerful build I can think of, then build batman or other cool builds once I know what I'm doing :)

Edit: Valerfor pointed out the -2AC penalty for huge size which I missed, so everything checks out. The Dragon's true AC is actually 98, not 100.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Oh, you're ridiculously committed Orion! Don't get me wrong. it's frighteningly laudable. But let's not get carried away with the "black box". I suspect that it's more a "can't be bothered/ didn't think of that" box. Maybe I'm getting a touch cynical...

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Orion is like the Mythbusters, Neverwinter Nights Edition.

For the test: I think the calculations were correct, let's see...

NPC Fighter AB: 34 (BAB) +10 (30 STR) +10 (Weapon, AB only) +2 (Flanking) = 56AB
PC Dragon: AC: 100 (Lie) -2 (Size penalty) -20 (Dodge) -8 (Tumble) = 70AC
He crits & confirms it with two hits 74AB & 72AB, but above that, he still misses you with an 69AB strike.

If your Dragon did not have UD then your Real AC while flat-footed would be reduced to 51AC from 98AC, that shows how careful one must be.
Although, to be fair, half or more of the times a character gets flat-footed is the game's own fault. Ayes on the left top corner guys!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: Size penalty of course! Thank you Valerfor!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
By the way I am going to use Stag's suggestion to put Int to 14. This guy needs skill points to solo effectively, for example I would want a search score up to about 10+, and one point in open lock. Listen is valuable against stealthy opponents. Going to edit the main post again soon. I think with a Cons of 9, I can boost it up with spells and equipment so I can manage that issue in that way.

My last decision is going to have to be regarding choice of deity which on WoG affects the domains I can use. 

I would prefer Trickery and Travel but that is limited on WoG to Sehanine Moonbow which requires one to be a half-elf or elf. If I take half elf I get +1 to search listen spot, sleep immunity and +2 to saves against mind affecting abilities at the expense of one feat. I am super feat starved so that is unattractive.

Trickery I think is too good to pass up for improved invisibility +50% concealment.

Which means I choose between knowledge, magic, chaos, evil, war, luck, protection, destruction and law.

Regarding the non-standard domains Chaos grants color spray, confusion and sphere of chaos. Law grants charm person, dominate person and lesser mind blank. Luck grants charm person, bestow curse and sphere of chaos. 

Of the NWN domains I think War is best for Cat's Grace and Aura of Vitality (which can be extended hurray!) or Destruction for the ability to use turn undead to also damage constructs (40d3 sounds very strong!).

I think Law would be best for the mind immunity spell, although Sphere of Chaos sounds amazing if its similar to the Baldurs Gate version. 

Anyway going to ponder this for a while before I decide. Maybe I will stick a post on the WoG forum for advice too.

Thanks everyone so much for reading this and for comments

posts.content:
Now we are talking, bravo for not giving up.

Two possible variations of the same thing:
a) Take exotic weapons instead & opt for a bastard sword (at 3rd-level).

b) Swap Cleric with Druid, same template as you have now, if you prefer SoV & Stonehold instead.
In order for this to work better, I would suggest changing Dev Crit & its feats with: SF: Conjuration, GSF: Conjuration, Empower Spell, ESF: Conjuration, Great Wisdom, finishing with WIS 20 & ESF: Conjuration.
This is just a more spellcasting oriented build with Druid instead of Cleric.

posts.content:
Devastating critical red mage pale master

I thought I could change bard to wizard to make this guy into a undead 'red mage' so to speak. ('undispellable' cleric 9 spells, wizard 6 spells, pale master crit immunity etc and dev crit scimitar)

The wizard caster levels will be pretty low plus arcane spell failure so the best usage of wizard will really be for the scribe scroll ability.

Anyway what do you think? Better than the other version? 

I lose the discipline skill but that could be managed with knockdown immune boots. 

UMD is a bit of a loss though in terms of equipping whatever item you want but he gains the ability to scribe up to level 6 wizard spells onto scrolls for use in combat (or to supply teammates).

Also Tumble as a class skill being lost means I lose 4 AC

Plus the ability to taunt enemies if I wish (I dont really use that skill but I probably should for the 'effective AB boost')

Is the base 36 AB good enough with all the cleric buffs to land critical hits? 

I could drop wizard 6 spells to lvl 5 spells for base 37 AB (see second version) but dunno if that is really worth it, being able to scribe keen edge, greater stoneskin and greater spell breach scrolls sounds pretty useful

I'm not really a big cleric or wizard player so the readers of this post probably know better than me
